Hi all, (mostly Kent and Erich ;-)

> I do not know whether this is a big problem, but /do not/ override 
> runTest().
Maybe the problem is in the JUnit Cookbook.
    http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/cookbook/cookbook.htm

Here is an excerpt:
1. Create an instance of TestCase:
2. Create a constructor which accepts a String as a parameter and passes
it to the superclass.
3. Override the method runTest()
4. When you want to check a value, call assertTrue() and pass a boolean
that is true if the test succeeds

I'm not sure, but this is probably for an older version of JUnit. When I
make tests, I don't do #2 and #3.

-- Shinobu

--
Shinobu Kawai <shinobu@..., shinobu@...>
